Award.AwardTitle: Extended and Novel Particle Sectors in String Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor James Halverson at Northeastern University.

String theory attempts to describe physical laws, such as those governing electromagnetism, nuclear physics, and gravity, in a common unified framework. One central aspect of string theory is that it predicts the existence of extra dimensions of space, and the properties of these extra dimensions play a large role in determining how particles interact in the theory. However, it turns out that there are many self-consistent possibilities for these extra dimensions in string theory. The central goal of Professor Halverson's research is to determine a set of very common possibilities and to analyze their corresponding predictions for potential additional laws of particle physics. Research in this area serves the national interest by promoting the progress of science at its most fundamental level, in this case by providing motivation for new physical laws from unified theories such as string theory. This project will also have substantial broader impacts. Professor Halverson will involve a postdoc and students in his research, and thereby provide critical training for junior physicists as they begin their research careers. He will also communicate his research results and related developments in the field to Boston-area high-school students through the NSF-funded Physics TheoryNet program, and also to his undergraduate students at Northeastern.

More technically, Professor Halverson will study the string landscape, using regions away from weak coupling and also string consistency conditions to motivate extended particle sectors (EPS) that are novel from the point of view of quantum field theory. One major aspect of this project will be the formal study of non-Higgsable clusters in F-theory, including their physical origin in four dimensions and associated implications for visible and dark EPS. He will develop new mathematics to understand the connection between matter and knots in the context of F-theory geometries, and will also study singular limits in G2 compactifications of M-theory and how string consistency conditions may require the existence of exotic matter. One potential contribution of this work is to develop a notion of typicality of certain EPS in the landscape, thereby providing motivation for models that are either novel or ad hoc in other physical frameworks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
String theory is a quantum mechanical theory of gravity that is a candidate theory for unifying gravity, elementary particle interactions, and early universe cosmology. However, the theory has a large number of solutions that give rise to different physical laws. Many questions then arise naturally: are the laws of physics that we observe consistent with string theory? Do they play some special role in string theory? Are they selected by some dynamical mechanism within string theory? The large number of solutions is known as the string landscape, and answering some or all of these questions are critical for determining the implications of string theory for particle physics and cosmology.


"Extended and Novel Particle Sectors in String Theory," an NSF grant to Professor James Halverson at Northeastern University, led to significant progress in understanding and approaching the string landscape, as well as its implications for elementary particle interactions and early universe cosmology. 


A major outcome of this project was the proposal of a new framework for addressing the string landscape using modern techniques from computer science, including supervised machine learning, reinforcement learning, and network science. These techniques are ideal for studying the string landscape, which is so enormous as to be intractable by brute force techniques, but nevertheless has structure that suggests using more sophisticated algorithms. The mentioned techniques involve some combination of an algorithm that can learn to perform useful tasks on its own, either by training on some fixed string dataset (supervised learning) or exploring a set of string theoretic possibilities intelligently (reinforcement learning). Results in applying these techniques to string theory include 1) rigorous theorems regarding contexts in which certain unified theories of particle interactions may arise in string theory, which were arrived at by machine-generated conjectures 2) orders of magnitude improvement in solving multi-task problems in the landscape related to the theoretical and experimental consistency of the theory, via reinforcement learning and 3) the demonstration of dynamical selection mechanisms in toy models of early universe dynamics using network science, where large ensembles of string geometries related by changes in their numbers of holes are represented by a mathematical graph. 


The latter was studied in an ensemble that itself was an outcome of this project: a new concrete ensemble of 10^{755} distinct geometries that could make up the extra dimensions of space in string theory. Despite the large number, Halverson et. al. showed that this ensemble has certain universal features, including rich particle sectors (both gauged and axion-like) that could have great importance for cosmology. Halverson et. al. demonstrated that these can lead to both cosmological pitfalls and opportunities, via the overproduction of dark matter and potential interactions between axion-like-particles and the photon. Both string theoretic possibilities differ significantly from perspectives developed by particle physics model builders, which was one of the goals of this project.


The project also led to major result in relating string theory to the Standard Model of particle physics, producing 10^{15} examples of fully consistent string compactifications that exhibit the exact gauge group and three-generation chiral matter spectrum of the (minimal supersymmetric) Standard Model. While the analysis is not yet complete, these models serve as excellent starting points for attempting to construct the non-supersymmetric Standard Model in string theory. When comparing to existing models with the same particle physics attributes, this new ensemble of about ten orders of magnitude more numerous.


Finally, the project also led to significant results in studying formal and theoretical aspects of string theory. This line of inquiry is essential, because a complete definition of string theory is not yet known, and making theoretical progress is almost certainly for a complete understanding of the string landscape and an understanding of string theory implications for particle physics and cosmology. Results include the development of new techinques to study string / M-theory on spaces with singularities, as well as development of new techniques on so-called G2 manifolds, which are a major topic of study in the mathematics community.
